density.note: Denser than water; household vinegar (~5% acetic acid) is slightly denser than pure water

specificHeat.note: About half of water's heat capacity

evaporationCoefficient.note: Hertz-Knudsen α coefficient. Lower due to dimerization (acetic acid forms hydrogen-bonded pairs). Range 0.01-1.0.

antoineCoefficients.TminC_note: EMPIRICALLY VERIFIED RANGE MINIMUM: The Antoine coefficients were experimentally validated down to this temperature. Calculations below this are extrapolated (smooth curve continues, but accuracy may degrade).
antoineCoefficients.TmaxC_note: EMPIRICALLY VERIFIED RANGE MAXIMUM: The Antoine coefficients were experimentally validated up to this temperature. Calculations above this are extrapolated (smooth curve continues, but accuracy may degrade).
antoineCoefficients.source: Published thermodynamic data for acetic acid vapor pressure; experimentally verified over 17-118°C range.

electricalConductivity.note: Weak acid; slight conductivity from ionization

acidity.note: Weak acid; vinegar's sourness comes from H⁺ ions

solubilityInWater.note: Fully miscible; household vinegar is ~5% acetic acid, 95% water
